commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Sub category  (4)(4)
2. Top tier  (5)
3. Ones who are out of cite, in brief?  (2)(2)
4. Congressional record?  (3)(4)
5. Assist, as a lifter  (4)


FOOT LONG
ATTIC
ET AL
SEX TAPE
ABET

My fastest time in the past year by nearly a half minute.

(About as long as your average pop song.)
TIL bicep is a colloquialism. What the muscle is actually called beats me

"Do you argue about the best Pok√©mon often?"
"No, I kind of Pikachus my battles."

(I bet they're off to the shopping center: gotta catch a mall!)
Normal easiness for Monday, but I appreciated the clues that went all the way across the grid.
Fun easy Monday. I had a hangup with NS_ and S_ABS, because I was unfamiliar with both, but just spamming different letters until I got the gold star worked lol
This was fun! Thanks so much!
I had N.S.A. before N.S.C. but Saabs didn‚Äôt fit so I knew it was scabs and N.S.C.. only fix this puzzle and 4 minutes shorter than my average. Nice Monday puzzle

An enjoyable few minutes. We've seen Rich a few times, it's nice that he brought you along for the ride, Katy.

Nice debut and thanks!

This one was pretty easy even for a Monday one, got it in 6:57, my PR is 6:40.  

Not often you get full width clues that you can get instantly without any cross clues.

PR by 22 seconds. 

Too bad the NYT changed the stats page. üëéüèª
11 seconds off my pb.

For our international solvers and those Americans not into sportsball, you might have had a little trouble with the crossing of 16A/18D, since both are about American football.

A TOUCHDOWN is scored by carrying the ball over your opponents' goal line or catching it (generally via a THROW by the quarterback) in their end zone.  It's the highest-scoring play in the sport, good for six points, with an opportunity to kick an extra point or run a play for two points.  (In most situations, teams opt for the single point because it's a near certainty.)

A PUNT is a play in which the team on offense concedes possession to the defense by kicking them the ball.  This usually happens on fourth down, which is the last of four chances to gain ten yards.  At the beginning of each play, the down and distance needed for the next first down is given in the format of these examples:  1st and 10 (normal starting situation), 2nd and 5 (after one play that gains five yards), 3rd and 2 (after a second play that gains another three yards), 4th and 2 (after a third play with no gain). Upon reaching fourth down, the offense can run another offensive play, but if they don't pick up the required yardage, the other team gets the ball at that spot.  Usually, the offense will choose to PUNT the ball downfield, especially if the distance to go is long ("4th and long"); the opposition still will gain possession, but this time much farther down the field.
After being frustrated on the Friday and Sunday puzzles this past week, it was nice to get a gimme. Would have liked a little chew though. My wine addled brain thought this was a little too easy.
13A's clue is incorrect. Google.com is rightly a URI; https://google.com is a URL (and a URI). Without the protocol, we cannot call it a URL.

I zipped through the solve, hence didn't CATCH the nuance of each theme entry using a different definition of the word "catch" (thank you, Sam!)
Now I'm even more sold on this puzzle.

This is really a perfect Monday for newbies to CATCH the crossword bug.

Thank you, Rich and Katy for a great start to the weekend. Please come back soon!

P.S. Here's The Cure with a very cute "Catch" ("You know I used to try to catch her, but never even caught her name...")
It‚Äôs 9:36 pm in Dallas, July 20. And my crossword puzzle is for Monday July 21. I‚Äôm using the app and this is a major bummer. Can anyone help me?

Well that was a quick fun one for me, who is otherwise in a rather foul mood for a very specific reason that occurred after an otherwise very lovely day. I don't need to go into it except to say that I'm grateful for the puzzle! I am always grateful for these puzzles, and I'm always grateful for you fine folk!  ‚ù§Ô∏è

I'm less grateful for the mosquitoes, who keep trying to bite me out here on our gorgeous garden balcony.  It's probably not gorgeous by most people's standards, certainly not magazine type standards, but there are lots of plants and life and I love it so much!! Especially my maroon and gold marigolds. Go Gophers!!

Currently, there's also a martini and a bunch of anti-mosquito candles out here, so things are improving. Hehehe! 

üíõ‚ù§Ô∏èüíõ

Did anyone else have deja vu? I was able to put this one away very, very fast because, I swear, I worked it before. I was jumping all over the site trying to understand what was happening, but nothing anywhere. Oh well, done now.

Cheers.

I think this may be the last post concerning the mother deer and her fawn that have been stopping by in our back yard.

We set up a cam to record them when we're not here, and one day the mother actually came up on the back deck, snooping around.

A few days later, I noticed something on the railing for that deck.  I went out to see what it was, and it was a rock, seemingly carefully placed on the railing in the most likely spot to be seen

The rock was interesting, a lot of quartz (I think), kind of pretty.  Not just an everyday rock.

I am loving the idea that the mother deer left it for us to thank us for the use of our back yard.  

Obviously I know that's not the case, but I prefer to believe that over the many more likely possibilities.
THE EVENING NEWS might not be a ‚ÄúGotta catch‚Äù for everyone ‚Äî but it‚Äôs not an ‚Äú‚Äôem‚Äù for anyone.
There should be an extra day before Monday to publish something like this. Just pointlessly effortless
This one was too easy‚Ä¶ or maybe I was just WIRED? Either way, a Monday and overall PR (and a first-ever sub-3:00 solve).

Today I was surprised to see me completion rate at 98%, which is weird because I always maintain 100%. There were like 8 new crosswords in my "in progress" list, all from a long time ago. Why on earth did they suddenly appear? I've only ever done 2024-2025 puzzles daily, and I'm working backwards completing others from the archive, currently in doing 2022 and 2023.
I tried some of the intruding older puzzles, and they were really painful - loads of outdated US references I had no hope of knowing, as well as a general higher prevalence of junk entries. 1D on one of them was FDIC - the oh-so-well-known Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. I just revealed the whole puzzle to get rid of it.
If there's a policy of adding crosswords to my "in progress" list without my knowledge please don't...

A shot across the bows from Sam Corbin ?

‚ÄúMay it brace us all for the uncertainty of the solving week ahead.‚Äù

It was a pleasant puzzle.  

Thanks to the constructors and congratulations on your NYT debut. An achievement for anyone.

What a perfect Monday puzzle! Pleasantly easy with a fun, non-groany theme. Kudos to the constructors üëçüèæ. I especially enjoyed the juxtaposition, of sorts, of the actress and president in the clue for ADAMS. I'm more familiar with her than him üòÇ.

Btw, does anybody else Rich KatZ would be a great rapper name? ü§£

I learned the word SCABS very recently, 2 or 3 years ago, playing Disco Elysium - one of the best video games I have ever experienced. The writing in it is mindbogglingly good: for what is actually quite a small game, the writers created a whole new world, with fascinating characters, a history, economy, and society, all described in some of the most intelligently sophiaticated and complex English I have ever heard or read. In fact, the English of Disco Elysium is so hard, a certain Polish gamers' community was reluctant to believe I was able to understand it - apparently I was the only one among them who could: all the rest played with the Polish translations enabled.

NEWT I learned, obviously, from the local witch, who turned me into one. I got better though.
First time I managed to complete a solve with just the down clues. I have been trying for a few months on Mon and Tues but have always come up short before
Using the term 'scabs' is very disappointing.  That term is meant as a pejorative against those who chose to work when others choose not to.

@HeathieJ

Please click the time stamp of your original post below - my reply to your reply there has been hidden by the infamous time stamp bug.
BTS is not a supergroup. They debuted as a group and then went solo, which is pretty common in K-pop.

I‚Äôm not here to flex my BICEP or correct a URL, nor to point out the hilarious rudeness of the word SPUNK to any Brit with an ounce of impishness, and not even to whinge about the excluding Americanisms (Heinie /TUSH?). I simply wish to celebrate the word PUNT. 

Does any other rarely-used word have so many meanings? I‚Äôve always loved it for this reason. Without looking it up, i am aware of these definitions:

A kick
A bet
A flat-bottomed boat
The bottom of a champagne bottle 
An Irish pound

Are there any more?

I think I may be the only one who found this slightly harder than usual for Monday. Looking at you American football, of course, and initialisms.

Also I don't know anything about Pokemon, really nothing. Having 'MALL' at the end didn't help! 
Thanks again to Steve for explaining. I should know PUNT by now. We have a comedian called Steve Punt, maybe I'll use that.

I won't comment on BrEnglish SPUNK.

SPUNK fnarr fnarr.
Ok, now I got that silliness out of my system: a perfect Monday puzzle. Straightforward but not boring with a well thought out theme.
What‚Äôs not to like?
Almost two decades as an English teacher and it‚Äôs a Monday crossword that causes me to learn what a zero plural noun is. Well-played.
Fun to see the spanners on a Monday puzzle.
Amy and John Quincy are quite the ADAMS odd couple,  but whatever.
These Monday puzzles get easier and easier.  My 23 year old grandson and his mother agree.  Why oh why are the editors dumbing them down?

Fun Monday and a pretty impressive piece of construction with all of those long answers. A couple of the theme answers actually came to me with no crosses and the others worked out quite smoothly. And of course the reveal was the last thing I got - just a nice touch.

And... no big deal but will just note that MIA is more than just 'an army absence.' Still a couple of guys from my company in Vietnam that remain MIA. Can't imagine what that's like for those families. 

And of course a puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply.

...

Did not know SCABS and had NSa instead of NSC, so was left wondering what SaABS could possibly have with picket lines üòÇ Needed to check the column to figure it out finally! But a fairly breezy, fun puzzle otherwise.

By the numbers:

ONE ‚Äì PuzzPair¬© in the cross of BUTT and TUSH.

TWO ‚Äì words that sound like letters (BEE, I SEE).  Also, rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilaps (ENOLA, PITON).  Also, that pair of abutting flat-bottomed boats (PUNT, BARGE).

THREE ‚Äì Theme answers (TOUCHDOWN PASSES, AIRPORT SHUTTLES, SPELLING ERRORS) that are appearing in the Times puzzle for the first time in its 80+ years.  ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù you object, ‚ÄúThey are all plurals.  Surely the singulars have been used before.‚Äù  And you would be wrong.

FOUR ‚Äì Distinctly different meanings of ‚Äúcatch‚Äù in the theme.  Impressive.  Also, the number of points TSAR gets in Scrabble, while its other spelling gets 15.

This was a stellar Monday puzzle with its terrific theme, and with any possible no-knows easily crossed.  This could make doing crosswords to a newer solver quite catchy, as it were.  

Thank you, Katy and Rich for starting the week with spark, and congratulations, Katy, on your NYT debut!
Thanks, NYT, for adding the Midi crossword puzzle. I appreciate having a little more crossword fun without breaking into the archive.
SCABS could have been clued better.. great little monday though!

A fine Monday puzzle with a pleasantly simple theme. 

Can't help but feeling it's already been a long time since THE EVENING NEWS was a must-catch offering.

Most of the connotations of SCABS are somewhat unpleasant, but when applied to people as in the clue the term seems borderline derogatory. Was a bit surprised to see that one.

Of all the entries, I think I spent the most time unscrambling AISLE. Took me much too long to see ELIAS.
I got the email about the midi and I'm happy to have another puzzle to do. Is it available in the app or just in the browser?
Very fun Monday!

I know the clue to 32D includes the word ‚Äúinformally,‚Äù but I just couldn‚Äôt bring myself to type the answer because I knew it was anatomically incorrect.  I filled it on the crossings instead, and consequently I think I may have to extend the scale of my cruciverbal prudery!  LOL

Thant‚Äôs my only nit to pick in a pleasant Monday puzzle.  Thanks as always to the constructors and editors who share their talents for our enjoyment.

Y‚Äôall have a lovely day, be kind, and stay cool.
I choose you, StenmetzKatzAchu! Fun start to the week.
yassssss first sub-5 minutes for me!
After doing The New York Times Monday Crossword, I go to The New Yorker Monday Crossword for a challenge. Did anyone else here do today's New Yorker puzzle? Did you find it a challenge?

Catchy puzzle! Thanks, Katy and Rich.

No, I haven't read the comments to see how many other folks have made the same obvious pun. 

Like Sam, my favorite clue was 50A, "sentance".

Now I need to GOBI useful.
4:01 today. Just two seconds slower than my fastest Monday.

Congrats on the NYT debut Katy Steinmetz.  Breezy fun.  

I was going to talk about Lou Grant's opinion of people with SPUNK but see Steve L just beat me to it (see below).  Was the first thing I though of.
50A contains only one spelling error. Their, fore, and hear are usage errors but are spelled correctly. Only sentance is a spelling error.

Let me be the 150th to point out that 50A is in ERROR.  Only "sentance" is a misspelled word.  The others--homonyms (or as some call them, homophones) --are spelled correctly but are not the right (intended) words.  
Just for kicks:  what's the most interesting/hilarious/astounding misspelling you've ever encountered?  My vote goes to PEACH'S FOR SALE.

Oh, the puzzle.  Starting with a rock group and ending with "celebrity gossip site" and Pok√©mon....  Thank goodness it's Monday and the Crosses were easy, because Katy and Rich were striking at my weakest areas.  

Spelling story:
One of my HS Special Ed students asked, "How do you spell ANUF?"  Of course I gave him "E-N-O-U-G-H," and he threw a fit.  He stamped his feet and flung his arms about, yelling, "ANUF!  ANUF!   I want to spell ANUF!"  He may have called me "an old bag," which was hilarious, as I was in my Twenties.  It was a doozy of a tantrum.  I would SO have loved to say, "You blithering idiot," but had to stay professional.  I don't know what became of Mike H., but I'd guess prison; he was in school by court order only until he turned 16.....and it was, indeed, a *happy birthday* for the whole class.
Flat-bottomed boats you make the rockin' world go 'round!
How is ‚Äúslay‚Äù to ‚Äúkill it in a good way‚Äù? What am I messing?
Ironically, a SPELLINGERROR was the only reason I didn‚Äôt set an all-time PB. Darn that O right above the K.
This was fun, Mondays are not that troubling to me. But, about the word "spunk," it always makes me think of The Ghost and Mr. Chicken. Attaboy Luther!

Did anyone have any idea about what the themers had in common? I love it when a revealer surprises me like that.

One of my favorite John Sayles movies, "Matewan", concerns labor organizing about a century ago. I wish more people knew who John Sayles is.



The Mini puzzle has gotten way too hard; it seems like forever since I got a gold star!

So close to a PB. Had Cote D‚ÄôAZUL and took me a good extra minute to find it :(

Fun Monday though. Can‚Äôt PB them all.

I wish there were separate speed records for puzzles completed on the desktop versus the phone. I‚Äôm limited by my clumsy thumbs on the phone; otherwise I think I would have been close to a record today. Also, there was only one spelling error. The other three were clearly caused by autocorrect guessing the wrong word!

I received an email today about the new midi crossword that apparently begins today. I used the link, found the puzzle, and solved it. But it‚Äôs nowhere to be seen on the Gameplay App. I tried refreshing the app, and seeing if there were any updates to no avail. What gives?
I‚Äôll be on the lookout for more ‚Äúcatchy‚Äù puzzles from this pair of collaborators.  A delightful Monday with charming spammers for the theme!

One of the easiest Monday puzzles I've solved.

(But I don't find "Gossip" a good clue for GAB, which to me means nothing more than talk.)

Absolutely LOVED this puzzle, y‚Äôall! The care and detail and fun twists! I had never cared to learn about Pok√©mon until our sixth grandchild started playing so that was fun. And the theme really appealed to my retired teacher sensibilities! (Especially 50 across)
Thank you, Puzzle Makers!
Your biceps are not used in a pull up. It should be lats or traps. Bicep would be more appropriate for a chin up.

Wonderful Monday puzzle, and wonderful debut for the constructing team. It was never frustrating but was also full of surprise and delight. Great start to the week. I had to correct one error to get the gold star, as I had NSa at 35D until I saw my mistake at 43A. 
Wishing you all a safe week.

On the easy side, even for a Monday. Finished in 4m42s. 

Thought it odd to clue MIA with something as banal as ‚Äúarmy absence‚Äù (which would be an apt clue for AWOL perhaps). I‚Äôm pretty sure the loved ones of those considered Missing In Action think of it as something more than a mere ‚Äúabsence‚Äù. Nor did I love SLUSH clued as ‚Äúwatery snow‚Äù. I suppose it‚Äôs not entirely incorrect but ‚Äúhalf-melted snow‚Äù would be better.
#Everybodyshutup:-0 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Gv0H-vPoDc&list=RD8Gv0H-vPoDc&start_radio=1 (My favorite moment is at 2:42)

Bonus themer to CATCH: Steelhead TROUT, my favorite gamefish and near obsession. While steelhead are derived from rainbow trout and share the same biologic name (Oncorynchus mykiss), they have adapted to the same life cycle as salmon, spawning in fresh water rivers of the Pacific and spending a year or two there before migrating as 6" smolts to the ocean. Most spend two or three years feeding and growing to 6-8 pounds and then return to their natal river to repeat the cycle. Unlike Pacific salmon which die after spawning, around 15% can survive the spawn and then go back to the ocean for another cycle. Some even spawn 3-4 times, coming back progressively larger, which make them an attractive gamefish. Most anglers realize that these fish are "too valuable to catch only once" and so practice catch-and-release. Although hatchery steelhead are delicious, you should never buy wild steelhead as they are increasingly endangered. The four H's (lost Habitat, over-Harvest, Hydropower dams and Hatchery fish which compete with wild fish) have lead to declines in numbers. Farmed steelhead and salmon are also not as sustainable as some would lead you to believe, because of the immense damage the fish farms do to the estuaries and their inhabitants where the net pen farms are anchored.

Obviously I liked the puzzle! I would have had a PB Monday but I had NSA and SAABS which took me 4 minutes to sort out. My son was a big fan of Pokemon so the themer was a gimme.

I‚Äôve been experiencing odd glitches more and more often lately, like working on a crossword, taking a break, and when I come back to it, a lot of filled words aren‚Äôt in the grid anymore.  It sometimes happens with other puzzles.  

Today has been really challenging.  I‚Äôve done the crossword twice, and it seems to be sticking, but Connections just won‚Äôt accept that I‚Äôve completed the puzzle.  The first correct set is permanently registered but when I finish the rest and try to go to the analysis, I‚Äôm told to finish the puzzle first and am sent back to the page, with one row completed.

Anyone else having problems like this, and if so how did you resolve them?
Excellent offering....just the thing for crossword newbies...as it should be for Mondays. Thanks Katy and Rich!!

I know bragging is bad but...today marked the 15th day of my streak, my best ever.  Based upon past performance, I should hit at least 17 days.  Nothing compared to the mavens on here but nobody else in my life would really care about this achievement so you guys are stuck with it.  Thanks .
Quick and fun solve this morning, got me my newest PB! Always a delight to see some of my favourite franchises like Pokemon mentioned in the crossword
Quick and easy solve, great to start the week. Thanks!
Super easy, one after another, Tra La la until 58 across, which brought it all to a screeching halt with truncated lazy words that spoiled a perfectly good puzzle.
Super fun puzzle! Unfortunately I have one complaint, and it's that BTS is definitionally not a supergroup
Haven‚Äôt had so many incorrect words on a Monday in a while! Took a couple of passes to catch ‚Äòem all.
BTS is back!!!
MIA carries a lot more context and weight than "army absence." This clue was pretty tone deaf. How about ___ Farrow next time.

I wonder what makes constructors decide to make a puzzle a Monday level since with the same grid but tougher clues it can readily be turned into a middle-of-the-week or Saturday one.  Or do tough puzzles require more complex grids?
MIA is a bit more than an absence.  Actually it‚Äôs a lot more than an absence.  Not good clueing.
This one was fun.
I grew up near Nice, France. My wife is from Des Moines. I appreciate you had Azur and Iowan cross.

If the quote in the clue for 30D can actually be attributed to Cicero and not a bumper sticker from a yoga retreat, I‚Äôll eat any of my hats: editor‚Äôs choice as to which one. (Except for my original Utah Utes hat; that one is a collectible by now. Or the Alta hat. Also vintage by now.)

@Lewis

Good choices, as always. I also thought the clue for EMOTIONAL was quite clever [Tearing up or breaking down]. My first thought was of ripping rather than crying.
@Anita -- Thank you.  I liked that one a lot as well, and it was definitely in the mix -- lovely play on "tearing".

@Lewis

So nice to have you back! I hope you had a good time away!!

Steve,

Glad you're feeling better.
Biceps.
@Steven M. I had the same thought, the "informally" there definitely threw me.
@Steven M. Without the "colloquialism," we'd have a dozen commenters pointing out that the correct singular form of that muscle is "biceps."

@Steven M.
The full name is biceps brachii, and there are 2 sets, short head and long head.  So "biceps" is the colloquialism.
@Steven M.  Not only are there the biceps brachii, commonly identified as ‚Äúbiceps‚Äù, there are also biceps femoris, yes in your legs.
@Steven M. P.S. ‚Ä¶so ‚Äúbiceps‚Äù referring to the former is not colloquial but rather, as in the clue, informal, being imprecise.

@Barry Ancona So it's like, I don't know if there's an exact term for this, but the backronym equivalent of a plural? Biceps, like the Trinidadian dish doubles, is a singular word. And referring to the muscle in one arm as a singular bicep is only acceptable in informal use?

You have a left biceps and a right biceps? Together they are your biceps, but alone one is still a biceps?

The term biceps brachii is a Latin phrase meaning "two-headed [muscle] of the arm", in reference to the fact that the muscle consists of two bundles of muscle, each with its own origin, sharing a common insertion point near the elbow joint. The proper plural form of the Latin adjective biceps is bicipites,[23] a form not in general English use. Instead, biceps is used in both singular and plural (i.e., when referring to both arms). The English form bicep, attested from 1939, is a back formation derived from misinterpreting the s of biceps as the English plural marker -s.[24][25] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biceps

@Steven M.

It's kinda like "pants", only different.
I liked them too, but entries in the grid are not clues.
@Barry Ancona You are correct.  I don't know why I wrote that but maybe it was the wine?

@Jonathan

I knew perfectly what you meant. Some people just like flagging every mistake they see.

I can understand that. If you've never been out of Alabama, you may have never seen a picket line.





Which Side Are You On?

@Barry Ancona Alabama has labor strikes too, and unfortunately as in other parts of the country /world,  labor often gets the short end of the stick. If you want to make your day a bit angrier and / or bleaker, suggested reading includes the Birmingham District Coal Strike of 1908. Same basic good vs evil setting as the Harlan County injustice which motivated Florence Reece. Labor hasn't tended to fare well in the decades since, either, but the New Flyer victory in Anniston can hopefully indicate a changing climate. 'Whose Side Are You On' favorite versions: Weavers + Pete Seeger's various versions, Dropkick Murphys, Ani DeFranco (updated lyrics) and the solo vocal of Florence Reece herself. If any others to recommend, please share.
@CB which!

CB,

It's not 1908.  
Alabama is a "right to work" state.
I learned The Weavers' version,
and I heard Pete Seeger sing it.
And I've sung it
My children are union members 
(and I was too, decades ago).

I knew as child that a SCAB was something more than the result of an injury.

@Barry Ancona

When I think of unions, I think of how it was through the my father's carpenter union health insurance that I was able to see a doctor when I was sick.

Bring them back.  Bring them back for good.  Pay people as if they were people, and not pack animals.

Gotta go.  I have to go make a picket sign.

@Barry Ancona

That's a strange comment. There are many ways to learn that word, such as watching the news, talking to friends, reading books, Social Studies class, etc. It wouldn't even cross my mind that perhaps Andy never left Alabama.

Mr Dave,

I trust you've never been in Alabama.

@JayTee

Well said.
@Chris agree- 6:09 for me!
@Steve L Lost me there but I know somehow that "punt" is like "put off and delay.'

@Steve L

Wonderful explanation!
And still I don't understand a word nor a thing about American football. 
Much to my father's chagrin, die-hard fan that he is, I watch only the Super Bowl, paying attention to the score and never the game. 

But I do appreciate the lengths to which you went to explain. Really amazing!

@sotto voce

A former boyfriend, actually, my last one before my husband, left me with one good thing. He explained to me that downs in US football were like tokens. You had four opportunities to get 10 yards. If you got to the 10 yards, then you got four more.  


On the 4th down, if you hadn't gotten 10 yd yet, you had to make a decision whether to go for it or punt, which is to try to kick it far away, and what your decision is usually based on where you were on the field...   because if you go for it on 4th down or fourth token, and miss, they take over from where you are, it might make it very easy for them to get to their own goal If you're closer to their goal than yours. 

Anyhow, enough of that, but just to say that understanding downs and how they worked was like what finally switched in my mind to help me understand the game. 

He wasn't really a great boyfriend. He felt like I shouldn't wear lipstick and he was constantly testing me on random history and other trivia. I always aced it, but I didn't like that he felt like that's what he should do to make sure I was an adequate potential partner. It wasn't a long relationship. But I always appreciate that I understand football now. I mean the downs were kind of just the basic thing and I built on it after that but it's nice to have a fond memory even if someone who wasn't overall all that great.

@HeathieJ

Yes, you elaborated on the concept of the downs, and the logic of why teams sometimes punted and other times went for it.  It's always good to get something valuable out of a relationship that didn't have that much going for it.

@HeathieJ

There was a commercial from many years, probably for beer, that I loved.

It was a couple.  The first scene was like in the early 60s, she was asking him what a "Brown" was, which is the mascot for the Cleveland team.   He rolls his eyes.

Then there's a latter one, in which they are both dressed like hippies, and she says, "He was called for holding?  But it's so nice to hold onto each other."   He rolls his eyes.

In the third one, present day, she's screaming at the TV "He didn't negotiate the linebacker!  Did you see that?  He didn't negotiate the linebacker!"

The final scene is the man sneaking a call to a friend to ask what "negotiating the linebacker" means.

@Steve L

‚ò∫Ô∏è

You are so right!! Because of my age and some other circumstances at the time, I thought he was my last chance. But when I realized I'd be better off alone, even if it was my last chance, which it totally wasn't, that was it for us.

And I totally agree. I try to always look for something good even in a difficult situation. It's not always possible, but most of the time there's something valuable to take away.

@Francis

üòÇ I don't remember that one, but that's pretty great!!!  üòÇ

@HeathieJ

The fact that you wanted to settle down didn't mean that you wanted to settle.

@Steve L

‚ù§Ô∏è

@Thomas

If we're being pedantic then without the scheme it is neither a URI nor URL. But in common parlance a domain name is a URL.

@Thomas  I came here to see whether anyone else had commented on that. Yep, Google.com is just a domain name. I realize that today, if you just type the domain name, today's web browsers will fill in the necessary information (https://) to locate that site, but the fact remains that the domain name itself is not a URL.

@Thomas You are correct that google.com is not a URL. However, it's not a URI, either. Both a URL and a URI must have a scheme (such as "https"). It would be correct to say that it's a domain name. The clue should be: https://google.com, e.g. I'm also not sure that I agree with the reply that a URL includes a bare domain name in common parlance; "URL" is a technical term with a specific meaning, as opposed to a more generic term like "web address".

Your garden sounds amazing, exactly like something I would love ‚ù§Ô∏è

My mother wanted a magazine-type garden, with great lawns, neatly planted flowers, trimmed shrubs. Since she died, my father and I have been implementing environmentally-positive policy there, though. Dad stopped mowing the lawn. Within months it transformed into the most beautiful meadow, full of flowers, abuzz with bees. It warms our hearts to think how thousands of creatures are benefitting from it. Also, water retention has improved greatly - the old garden required regular watering. The new one needs no watering at all. My beloved dog resting forever under all that life and beauty gives me peace.

@Jane Wheelaghan Re: SPUNK The Mary Tyler Moore Show was a groundbreaking sitcom in the 70s because it depicted the life of a single woman in a city making it on her own. The very first episode got the public's attention, in great part because of Mary's interview with her soon-to-be boss, Lou Grant. Here's the most pertinent exchange: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0cHSYhafCQM And for more context, the previous exchange takes place just after the three-minute mark in this longer clip: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z6WtXwhWqZw We know what SPUNK means in the UK (it can mean it here, too, in the right context), but in these clips you see how it's usually used.

I had a 'client' who was clearly bright, but if I'd seen her dissertation draft first I'd have had my doubts.  She was asea, as crosswords would say.

@Mean Old Lady But those words, although they have similar pronunciations, are not homophones. So that was a usage error.

@Mean Old Lady

Your post makes me very sad. When I was part of a special services support group for parents of special ed kids, part of my role was talking to parents whose children had just been identified. Most of them were being told by their mothers-in-law, who inevitably had at some point worked in a school system, not to let their kids be "labelled." And I would say, which label would you rather they had? LD or JD? Stupid or learning disabled? Your MikeH probably had a sad back story and a school district that tossed him in a group setting with little or no one-to-one attention. And no follow-up at home. This is not criticism on the classroom teacher, it's for the system he went through before he ever got to middle school, or even second grade.

@Marlene Thank you for your post. It didn't make me sad, it made me angry. As the parent of an ID/DD son, I have run into my share of ignorant or worse, non-caring special ed professionals and I submit that Mean Old Lady certainly was--and worse, proud of it . That she could laugh at this poor kid with so many strikes against him and dismiss him as a possible prison candidate tells me how unfit she was for the job. You can learn all the special ed theory you can swallow. But if you don't have a kind heart and a way of seeing into special ed brains, you should get out and find a nice job in retail.

@Marlene
Background:  the district was a small rural one about a half-hour west of Cincinnati.  There was only one special education teacher in each school, so my HS sp-ed class had a range of 'labels,' abilities, etc.  (This was also well before 94-142.)  Aside from a few with serious learning impairment (MR, LD, low vision), only the kids who were behavior problems were tested and placed.  Mike was in that group.  I made home visits, so I knew more background than was usual.  He was actually sharper than the other students, but determined to do very little (except pick on other kids.)  It was sad, but the class was relieved when he left school at 16.
@Mean Old Lady  You still used the anecdote to laugh at the kid. You used the word 'hysterical.' Not funny. Not kind. No excuse.

@upperwestside2
Wow.  

I spent a lot of years loaded for bear--living with anger that was easily triggered--dealing with medical and educational professionals who were supposed to be helping my two offspring with special needs, so I can recognize the ever-ready hair-trigger reaction.  
I'm sorry for your pain, but I don't deserve your opprobrium.

@RozzieGrandma
It was a bit more complicated than that.  The student was mispronouncing "enough" and was sure that it didn't start with an E--a flimsy excuse to act out, but eventually he understood that everyday speech was often a bit casual.  (Explaining 'schwa' wasn't in the cards..)  
English orthography does have some extra challenges, with borrowed words, ancient words (think about know, kneel, etc., that have persisted in our language), and irregularities.  However, it's 85% phonetically regular.  
People have different brains, and there are "all kinds of minds," as a noted authority once titled a book.  Good spellers usually have good visual memory and perception.  My sister (with a PhD) often confuses the order of letters in speech and in writing ("amino-centesis" instead of "amnio"; Pashima instead of Pashmina, nickle for nickel, and puzzel for puzzle.)  It has little to do with intelligence, and people work out how to manage.  I taught 'strategies' like thinking "Pract ICE" or "Re-CE-IVE" for dealing with spelling that seemed to make no sense.  Sometimes it spills over into reading, like seeing 'hilarious' and thinking and saying 'hysterical.'  We all have our little issues, but flying off the handle never helps in any setting--something we hope our kids outgrow.
See definition 2. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/slay

@Remy

You might want to repeat this question tomorrow, earlier in the day, so some of our more expert commenters can answer you. But I'll take a stab at it.

Constructing an easy puzzle is a different sort of challenge, to make it easily doable but not boring. That can be difficult if you're used to solving and making tougher puzzles and have devilishly clever clues floating around in your head.

The tougher puzzles do tend to use different grids, because they want to use less 3-letter fill. And they often want to work in some stacks (row upon row) of long answers.
